STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 8, 2023
Lindsey Lassanske
NEWAYGO/LAKE COUNTY DHHS
1018 E NEWELL ST,
WHITE CLOUD, MI, 49349-8795
Re: License #: CP620201323
Dear Lindsey Lassanske:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
September 8, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Services

Name of Agency: NEWAYGO/LAKE COUNTY DHHS

WHITE CLOUD, MI 49349-8795
Agency Telephone #: 2316895500
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1990
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90 calendar days
thereafter.
Two of six foster care files reviewed (2 of 21 service plans) did not have the
Updated Service Plan completed timely.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
2

(h Any other known information to enable the
foster parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster
family, including information about siblings who do
not reside in the foster home.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframe outlined within the rule.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate including those of parent(s)/guardian(s),
foster care worker, supervisor, foster parent,
caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the
local DHS office designee.
Two of six foster care files reviewed (6 of 27 service plans) did not contain all of the
required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/31/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
10/26/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 12/7/2021
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days as required.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have the supervisory approval of the
case service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/31/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
3

passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's
placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided
must be
documented in the electronic case management
record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a
temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are
not
required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the
child is newly referred to and accepted for treatment
and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled
appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of
placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• • Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
age 16
and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults
age 18
and older).
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young
adult:
• Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster
care.
• Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
4

Five of eight foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/31/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
10/26/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 12/7/2021
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three business
days after an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-
down from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Five of six foster care files reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/31/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
10/26/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 12/7/2021
5

FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, and/or DHS-901
semiannual must be completed for every
FTM/semiannual.
The caseworker must enter the FTM/semiannual
information in MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink
within seven business days of the FTM.
Four of six foster care files reviewed contained FTM's/semi-annuals without the
DHS 1105/901 or the DHS 1105/901 was not uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/31/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
10/26/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 12/7/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Medical passports need to be generated and uploaded quarterly.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Upload Help Desk ticket information under specific area, if possible. For
example, if USP was late due to system issue upload the ticket information there.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the renewal
inspection completed on 8/31/2022 with a corrective action plan approved on
9/22/2022. During the review the agency had eight violations. Five citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency noted that compliance was impacted, in part, by noncompliant
parents, scheduling conflicts with physicians and staffing changes.
6

Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency's efforts in meeting licensing requirements
during this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the previous year
CAP has had a positive impact on overall compliance. The CAP was successfully
implemented after developing it with staff and supervision. The CA also noted the
agency has experienced noncompliant parents, scheduling conflicts with primary
physicians and staffing changes that have impacted compliance.
The CA indicated the agency has continued to utilize the previous year CAP and
noted some of the positive impacts are special evaluation checklist, monthly social
work contact review protocols and additional training opportunities. The CA
expressed confidence the agency will continue to see improvement over the next
review period.
Financial Overview
NA
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by supervision as well as coworkers. Staff also reported the transition to
a new Director has gone well. There were no concerns reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
7

Licensing Consultant
